title: Shape
description: The shape scale defines the style of container corners, offering a range of roundedness from square to fully circular.

contentChunks.altText: Illustration showing the corner radii of 7 shape styles

contentChunks.htmlValue:
• Circular or pill shaped components use the fully rounded corner style rather than a fixed mapping to ½ of the dp value of the component. This ensures the shape remains circular even if the component scales. 
  • The default shape family is rounded. 
  • By default, shape styles are applied symmetrically on all corners, but asymmetric styles can be defined for a container’s corners at top, bottom, start, or end.

The expanded M3 shape system uses a size-based scale with seven styles. Styles are assigned to components based on the desired amount of roundedness or corner cut. For rounded corners, square-cornered shapes are “none” and slightly rounded shapes are “extra-small,” while entirely rounded shapes are “full.”

This is a change from the M2 shape system, where components were grouped by container size.

The new M3 shape system is more like the typescale, enabling an expressive range of shapes across the UI.

contentChunks.footer: Steps on the scale are named for the size of the curve or cut applied to the corner.
contentChunks.altText: 4 rectangles with a range of corner radii including none, extra small, small, and medium

contentChunks.footer: M2: Three-level shape scale based on the size of the component container.
contentChunks.altText: components illustrating the old 3-level shape scale

contentChunks.footer: M3: Seven-level shape scale based on the roundedness of shape corners.
contentChunks.altText: components illustrating the new 7-level shape scale

contentChunks.htmlValue:
The scale is a range of seven corner shape styles defining the amount of cut or roundedness: None, extra small, small, medium, large, extra large, and full.

Each role in the scale defines two things:

  • Shape family (rounded or cut)
  • Value

By default all roles use the rounded shape family. Most values are expressed in absolute dp measurements, except for the full style which is expressed in percentage.

Apply shape styles using tokens.

contentChunks.footer:
1. None 
2. Extra small 
3. Small 
4. Medium 
5. Large
6. Extra large 
7. Full
contentChunks.altText: Shape scale showing all 7 levels for rounded and cut corner styles

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Baseline shapes

By default, every component is mapped to one of the seven shape styles.

Symmetry

Components can have either symmetric or asymmetric corner shapes. Symmetric shapes have the same values for all corners, while asymmetric shapes can have corners with different values. A shape token that ends with a “directional modifier” – such as top, bottom, start, or end – is always asymmetrical.

contentChunks.footer:
1. Extra small top 2. Large top 3. Large end 4. Extra large top
Tokens for asymmetrical shapes include a “directional modifier” like top, bottom, start, or end.
contentChunks.altText: 4 shapes illustrating symmetrical and asymmetrical styles

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Shape family

Components can have one of two shape families:

  • Rounded corners
  • Cut corners

contentChunks.altText: rounded shape and cut corner shape

contentChunks.htmlValue:
For a style

You can customize the shape family and size of any style level in the shape scale. Such changes affect all components mapped to that shape style, except for those with an override.

contentChunks.footer: Customizing the corner size of the Medium style applies the change to all components using this style, such as cards and small FABs.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
For a specific component

You can change the style level that a component is mapped to.

For example, by default, buttons are mapped to the shape style “full.” If your product requires a smaller amount of roundedness, it can be remapped to the small or medium style in shape scale.

contentChunks.footer: Remapping the button shape to a different style applies the change to all buttons in the UI.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Changing the shape family can affect content within a component.

For example, a large cut corner on a card will intrude on the content area more than a rounded corner of the same size, potentially affecting the layout of content or clipping images. To avoid unintended results, consider the choice of shape family and size in tandem with a component's layout and content.

contentChunks.footer: To avoid unintended results, consider the choice of shape family and size in tandem with a component's layout and content.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Learn more about design tokens.
